title: Problem Overview
content:
**Erdős Problem #1098: Non-Commuting Graphs of Groups**

**Question:** If Γ(G) (non-commuting graph) has no infinite clique, is there a finite bound on clique sizes?

**Answer: YES** (Neumann 1976)

**Key Result:** No infinite clique ⟺ Z(G) has finite index. Bound = [G : Z(G)].
mathContext: This problem connects group theory (center, index) with graph theory (clique number).

title: Non-Commuting Relation
content:
**nonCommuting g h:**

Two elements g, h ∈ G do not commute if gh ≠ hg.

This is a symmetric relation (if g doesn't commute with h, then h doesn't commute with g).

title: Center of a Group
mathContext: The center is always a normal subgroup, and its index determines clique size bounds.

title: Non-Commuting Graph
content:
**NonCommGraph G:**

Γ(G) has:
- Vertices: elements of G
- Edges: between g and h if gh ≠ hg

This is an undirected graph (symmetric, irreflexive relation).

title: Cliques and Clique Number
content:
**isClique S and hasFiniteCliqueNumber:**

A clique is a set S where every distinct pair doesn't commute.

**hasFiniteCliqueNumber:** ∃ n, all cliques have size ≤ n.

**noInfiniteClique:** Every clique is finite.

title: Finite Index Center
content:
**centerHasFiniteIndex G:**

[G : Z(G)] < ∞, i.e., Z(G) has finite index in G.

This is equivalent to having finitely many cosets of Z(G).
mathContext: The key insight is that clique size is bounded by the number of cosets.

title: Neumann's Theorem (1976)
content:
**neumann_theorem and neumann_bound:**

**Equivalence:** Γ(G) has no infinite clique ⟺ Z(G) has finite index.

**Bound:** If [G : Z(G)] = n, then every clique has size ≤ n.

This completely solves Erdős' question.

title: Coset Structure
content:
**same_coset_commute and clique_different_cosets:**

**Key insight:** If g and h are in the same coset of Z(G), they commute!

Because g⁻¹h ∈ Z(G) means g⁻¹h commutes with g, so gh = hg.

Thus clique members must be in different cosets, giving the bound.
mathContext: This is the heart of the proof - the coset structure forces the bound.

title: Abelian Groups
content:
**abelian_no_edges:**

If G is abelian, Z(G) = G, so Γ(G) has no edges at all.

**infinite_clique_example:**

Non-abelian groups can have infinite cliques (e.g., free groups).

title: Summary: SOLVED
content:
**erdos_1098 and erdos_1098_summary:**

**STATUS: SOLVED** (Neumann 1976)

**Answer:** YES - if no infinite clique, then cliques are uniformly bounded.

**The bound:** Clique size ≤ [G : Z(G)].

**Equivalence:** No infinite clique ⟺ finite index center.
